verses.text: At that time, Jesus was walking through the grain fields on the Sabbath. His disciples were hungry, and began to pick the heads of grain and eat them.
verses.comment: The disciples’ actions, permitted under the Law for the hungry, would later be scrutinized for breaking Sabbath tradition. Shows the humanity and need of the disciples.

verses.text: But when the Pharisees saw this, they said to Him, 'Look, Your disciples are doing what is not lawful to do on the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: The Pharisees point to a traditionally strict interpretation of Sabbath law, emphasizing ceremonial over merciful observance.

verses.text: He replied to them, 'Have you not read what David did when he and those with him were hungry?
verses.comment: Jesus references Old Testament precedent. David—God's anointed—showed that mercy can surpass ritual.

verses.text: 'How he entered the house of God and they ate the bread of the Presence, which was not lawful for him or for those with him to eat, but only for the priests?'
verses.comment: God allowed David an exception for necessity. Anticipates how Jesus fulfills and transcends the OT priesthood.

verses.text: 'Or have you not read in the Law, that on the Sabbath the priests in the Temple break the Sabbath and are guiltless?'
verses.comment: Priests work on Sabbath for sacred duty. Jesus is guiding toward understanding the primacy of worship and mercy.

verses.text: I tell you, something greater than the Temple is here.
verses.comment: Jesus refers to Himself as greater than the Temple, claiming divine prerogatives. Here is a high christology: Jesus is God's presence incarnate.

verses.text: If you had known what this means—'I desire mercy and not sacrifice'—you would not have condemned the innocent.
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Hosea, teaching mercy has precedence over ritual. Interpreted both spiritually and literally: loving God and neighbor comes before ceremonial observance.

verses.text: For the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath.
verses.comment: Claim of divinity: Jesus exercises authority over the law, using the messianic 'Son of Man' title. This situates Him above tradition and temple.

verses.text: He went on from there and entered their synagogue.
verses.comment: Jesus enters the heart of Jewish worship, setting the stage to further interpret Sabbath laws.

verses.text: There was a man there with a withered hand. They asked Him, 'Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?'—so that they might accuse Him.
verses.comment: This is a test—will Jesus place mercy above tradition? The Pharisees seek grounds for accusation.

verses.text: He said to them, 'If any of you has a sheep and it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, will you not take hold of it and lift it out?'
verses.comment: Jesus points to practical mercy even on Sabbath, drawing analogy from Law. Shows that care for living beings takes precedence over legalism.

verses.text: 'How much more valuable is a man than a sheep! So it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath.'
verses.comment: Affirms the dignity and worth of the human person. Law is fulfilled by love of neighbor—direct implication for the sacraments and works of mercy.

verses.text: Then He said to the man, 'Stretch out your hand.' And the man stretched it out, and it was restored, healthy as the other.
verses.comment: Jesus works a public miracle, exhibiting divine compassion and power. His miracles often foreshadow sacramental grace.

verses.text: But the Pharisees went out and plotted against Him, how they might destroy Him.
verses.comment: Religious leaders oppose Jesus, foreshadowing His passion. Contrast between mercy and rejection by those clinging to external religion.

verses.text: Jesus, aware of this, withdrew from there. Many followed Him, and He healed them all.
verses.comment: Jesus responds to opposition with continued mercy. The crowd demonstrates the universal reach of His healing.

verses.text: He strictly ordered them not to make Him known.
verses.comment: Jesus often commands secrecy, emphasizing humility and the gradual revelation of His mission.

verses.text: This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet Isaiah:
verses.comment: Matthew highlights fulfillment of prophecy: the Messiah operates quietly and gently, preferring mercy.

verses.text: 'Behold, My servant whom I have chosen, My beloved in whom My soul delights. I will put My Spirit upon him, and he will proclaim justice to the nations.'
verses.comment: Direct reference to the Servant songs, showing Jesus as God’s Spirit-filled chosen one, with universal scope.

verses.text: 'He will not quarrel or cry out, nor will anyone hear his voice in the streets.'
verses.comment: Emphasizes the gentle, patient approach of Christ; His kingdom is not advanced by violence or political agitation.

verses.text: 'A bruised reed he will not break, and a smoldering wick he will not extinguish, until he leads justice to victory.'
verses.comment: Jesus ministers gently to the weak, supporting those wounded in spirit. This mercy points toward sacramental healing and pastoral care.

verses.text: 'And in his name the nations will put their hope.'
verses.comment: Universal salvation in Christ is affirmed. His mission is for all people, foreshadowing the international scope of the Church.

verses.text: Then a demon-possessed man who was blind and mute was brought to Him. Jesus healed him, so that he could speak and see.
verses.comment: Shows Jesus' authority over spiritual evil, restoring physical and spiritual senses. Considered a sign of the messianic age.

verses.text: All the crowds were amazed and said, 'Could this be the Son of David?'
verses.comment: Recognition as Son of David shows expectation of Messiah as both king and healer. High messianic fulfillment.

verses.text: But when the Pharisees heard it, they said, 'It is by Beelzebul, the prince of demons, that this man casts out demons.'
verses.comment: The religious leaders accuse Jesus of demonic power, demonstrating hardness of heart and spiritual blindness.

verses.text: Knowing their thoughts, Jesus said to them, 'Every kingdom divided against itself is laid waste, and no city or house divided against itself will stand.'
verses.comment: Jesus exposes the absurdity of their accusation with logical argument. If He were in league with Satan, Satan's kingdom would collapse.

verses.text: 'And if Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself. How then will his kingdom stand?'
verses.comment: Logical demonstration continues—evil does not cast out evil. Affirms Christ’s unique power over spiritual forces.

verses.text: 'And if I cast out demons by Beelzebul, by whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore, they will be your judges.'
verses.comment: His critics are inconsistent. Jesus points to Jewish exorcists—if their work isn’t demonic, why accuse Him?

verses.text: 'But if I cast out demons by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God has come upon you.'
verses.comment: Jesus reveals Himself working in the power of God’s Spirit. The kingdom breaking forth is found in His own presence.

verses.text: 'Or how can someone enter a strong man’s house and plunder his goods, unless he first binds the strong man? Then he may plunder his house.'
verses.comment: Jesus presents Himself as conquering Satan—the ‘strong man’—and liberating the captives. Prophetic fulfillment.

verses.text: 'Whoever is not with Me is against Me, and whoever does not gather with Me scatters.'
verses.comment: Jesus claims absolute allegiance, dividing all humanity into only two camps. Implies unity under Christ alone—pointing to the one holy apostolic Church.

verses.text: 'Therefore I say to you, every sin and blasphemy will be forgiven men, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven.'
verses.comment: Warning against final rejection of God’s grace. Blasphemy against the Spirit refers to persistent, unrepentant hardness of heart.

verses.text: 'Whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven, either in this age or in the age to come.'
verses.comment: Shows gravity of rejecting the Spirit’s witness. Note reference to 'age to come'—underlines idea of post-mortem accountability, often associated with purgation and final judgment.

verses.text: 'Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree bad and its fruit bad. For the tree is known by its fruit.'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches the necessity of interior righteousness. Good works must flow from a renewed heart—a concept foundational for faith and practice.

verses.text: 'You brood of vipers! How can you speak good, when you are evil? For out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaks.'
verses.comment: Jesus denounces hypocrisy. Heart transformation is essential, related to renewal by the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: 'The good man out of his good treasure brings forth good, and the evil man out of his evil treasure brings forth evil.'
verses.comment: Interior life overflows into action. True holiness is not just professed, but lived and embodied.

verses.text: 'But I tell you, on the Day of Judgment people will give account for every careless word they speak.'
verses.comment: Warning of final judgment and accountability. Suggests a thorough, even purifying, judgment process.

verses.text: 'For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned.'
verses.comment: Speech reveals the state of the heart; justification includes works and words, relating to living faith.

verses.text: Then some of the scribes and Pharisees answered Him, saying, 'Teacher, we want to see a sign from you.'
verses.comment: Despite His miracles, they demand more proof—a sign of hardness of heart and unbelief.

verses.text: He answered them, 'An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah.'
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes those who demand proof without faith; ‘sign of Jonah’ foreshadows His resurrection.

verses.text: 'For just as Jonah was three days and three nights in the belly of the huge fish, so will the Son of Man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.'
verses.comment: Direct allusion to His death and resurrection. A high christology—Jesus foreknows and controls His destiny.

verses.text: 'The men of Nineveh will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, because they repented at the preaching of Jonah. And look, something greater than Jonah is here.'
verses.comment: Jesus surpasses the prophets. Repentance is required; the openness of the pagans contrasts with the closed hearts of the religious.

verses.text: 'The queen of the South will rise up at the judgment with this generation and condemn it, for she came from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon, and look, something greater than Solomon is here.'
verses.comment: Jesus again claims superiority to Solomon, the wise king. Those outside Israel respond better than the insiders.

verses.text: 'When an unclean spirit goes out of a person, it passes through waterless places seeking rest, but finds none.'
verses.comment: Describes spiritual realities behind exorcism. Deliverance is incomplete unless filled with God’s grace.

verses.text: 'Then it says, ‘I will return to my house from which I came.’ When it comes, it finds the house empty, swept, and put in order.'
verses.comment: Emptiness after deliverance invites further evil unless filled with God. Alludes to need for ongoing sanctification and sacramental life.

verses.text: 'Then it goes and brings with it seven other spirits more evil than itself, and they enter and dwell there; and last state of that person is worse than the first. So it will be with this evil generation.'
verses.comment: Warning against mere external reform. Jesus encourages interior renewal and perseverance in grace.

verses.text: While He was still speaking to the crowds, His mother and His brothers stood outside, wanting to talk to Him.
verses.comment: Mary and Jesus’ kin seek Him, indicating family inclusion but also the transition to spiritual family.

verses.text: Someone told Him, 'Look, Your mother and Your brothers are standing outside, wanting to speak to You.'
verses.comment: The report sets up Jesus’ teaching about spiritual kinship in God’s family, broadening community beyond biological ties.

verses.text: But He replied to the one telling Him, 'Who is My mother, and who are My brothers?'
verses.comment: Jesus asks a question to shift the definition toward spiritual bonds emerging from obedience to God’s will.

verses.text: Then He stretched out His hand toward His disciples and said, 'Here are My mother and My brothers!'
verses.comment: The new family of Christ is formed through discipleship. Here Jesus shows that the Church is a spiritual household.

verses.text: For whoever does the will of My Father in heaven is My brother and sister and mother.
verses.comment: Jesus finalizes the definition of spiritual family. Obedience and communion form membership in God’s household—a foundation of the one, united apostolic community.
